sect1.title: Integers
sect1.simpara: An integer is a number of the set Z = {..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ...}.

sect2.title: Syntax
sect2.simpara: Integers can be specified in decimal (base 10), hexadecimal (base 16), or octal (base 8) notation, optionally preceded by a sign (- or +).
sect2.para: To use octal notation, precede the number with a 0 (zero). To use hexadecimal notation precede the number with 0x.

example.title: Integer literals
example.programlisting: <?php $a = 1234; // decimal number $a = -123; // a negative number $a = 0123; // octal number (equivalent to 83 decimal) $a = 0x1A; // hexadecimal number (equivalent to 26 decimal) ?>

The size of an integer is platform-dependent, although a maximum value of about two billion is the usual value (that's 32 bits signed). 64-bit platforms usually have a maximum value of about 9E18. PHP does not support unsigned integers. Integer size can be determined using the constant PHP_INT_SIZE, and maximum value using the constant PHP_INT_MAX since PHP 4.4.0 and PHP 5.0.5.

warning.para: If an invalid digit is given in an octal integer (i.e. 8 or 9), the rest of the number is ignored.

sect2.title: Integer overflow
sect2.para: If PHP encounters a number beyond the bounds of the integer type, it will be interpreted as a float instead. Also, an operation which results in a number beyond the bounds of the integer type will return a float instead.

example.title: Integer overflow on a 32-bit system
example.programlisting:
<?php
$large_number = 2147483647;
var_dump($large_number);                     // int(2147483647)

$large_number = 2147483648;
var_dump($large_number);                     // float(2147483648)

$million = 1000000;
$large_number =  50000 * $million;
var_dump($large_number);                     // float(50000000000)
?>

example.title: Integer overflow on a 64-bit system
example.programlisting:
<?php
$large_number = 9223372036854775807;
var_dump($large_number);                     // int(9223372036854775807)

$large_number = 9223372036854775808;
var_dump($large_number);                     // float(9.2233720368548E+18)

$million = 1000000;
$large_number =  50000000000000 * $million;
var_dump($large_number);                     // float(5.0E+19)
?>

sect2.para: There is no integer division operator in PHP. 1/2 yields the float 0.5. The value can be casted to an integer to round it downwards, or the round function provides finer control over rounding.

informalexample.programlisting: <?php var_dump(25/7); // float(3.5714285714286) var_dump((int) (25/7)); // int(3) var_dump(round(25/7)); // float(4) ?>

sect2.title: Converting to integer
sect2.simpara: To explicitly convert a value to integer, use either the (int) or (integer) casts. However, in most cases the cast is not needed, since a value will be automatically converted if an operator, function or control structure requires an integer argument. A value can also be converted to integer with the intval function.

sect3.title: From floating point numbers
sect3.simpara: When converting from float to integer, the number will be rounded towards zero.
sect3.para: If the float is beyond the boundaries of integer (usually +/- 2.15e+9 = 2^31 on 32-bit platforms and +/- 9.22e+18 = 2^63 on 64-bit platforms), the result is undefined, since the float doesn't have enough precision to give an exact integer result. No warning, not even a notice will be issued when this happens!

warning.para: Never cast an unknown fraction to integer, as this can sometimes lead to unexpected results.
See also the warning about float precision.

caution.simpara: The behaviour of converting to integer is undefined for other types. Do not rely on any observed behaviour, as it can change without notice.
